comments.commentBody: I have no complaints about this puzzle.  Plenty of other stuff ticks me off, such as why I should give a rat's butt that Bono has seen "Spider-Man," as is advertised on the right side of my screen as I type this insipid comment.  The puzzle, though was fine.  There does seem to be a perverse, inverse relationship between the amount of expected enjoyment and the amount of actual enjoyment produced by a wide open grid.  You think they'll be real chewy, but once you get a few of the short down answers, you're filling in that long answer with lightning speed.  Took me til the last square (M) to see the word ALMANAC--kept trying to make it "atlas" or "calendar."  Ol' Jokin' Joe K, he's a right clever son of a gun.
Thanks, Joe. I've updated the post to reflect that, but I still admire your construction.

I also think it is time for the Clerk of the House and the Clerk of the Senate to assign member's seats instead of just letting them congregate into their little cliques. Group the members by State so members of Congress have to talk to each other.

This is even more important in the Senate because they have traditionally divided the chamber into Republican and Democratic sides. Seat them by State and let them talk to each other. If that doesn't work, do a random assignment which alternates Republican, Democrat, Republican, ....

One would imagine that even in liberal and democratic Tucson, there must have been many people at the rally that were armed that could have taken out the shooter. Yet the real heros that finally stopped Loughner were unarmed. So much for the argument we need guns to protect each other, or that a state packing more heat than the 8th Army is any deterent to criminals or lunitics.

Being from Arizona, when I see some one wearing a gun, and a lot of people do there, my first thought is: "Is this guy crazy?" My second thought is "How much of a coward is this guy-really?".

OK, gun control is politically tough, the catch 22 is that existing law forbids sale of a gun to the mentally ill, but unless a mentally ill person has been hospitalized or been picked up by police and recorded as having mental problems -they do not get on the restricted sales list.

So first improvement to existing gun laws would be to make submitting to an MMPI and a mental evaluation an iron clad requirement for buying a gun. Period. That would be a big start in controlling this nonsense, short of banning handguns outright.

I'm not a gun enthusiast but recognize that people have a right to carry a weapon to protect themselves.

But a handgun that can shoot 30 bullets in a matter of seconds? I read that people want this privilege because many use these weapons on a firing range. Reloading all the time -- after say nine or twelve shots -- is too difficult. That's a pretty rough trade off: convenience at a firing range for safety.

Again, no problem with the general and broad right to carry to protect oneself. But I see no reason for the handgun that shoots 30 bullets in seconds.

Would public sentiment or NRA position change if all members of congress toted guns, both concealed and open?

I wish all 100 Senators and all 435 members of the House of Representatives would show up at their next legislative sessions with legally acquired guns, and all the concomitant permits. That _might_ distill some people's positions in a hurry...

I am so tired of being told that standing up against ALL killing is a "liberal" position, unless, of course, I am unwilling to bring a child into a world economy that wants to return to serfdom, and whose streets s/he plays on may not be safe from gunshot...

My abhorrence of guns extends to my abhorrence of war, and to my disgust that our national apathy is so great that extremely few protest the war, and that people watch 500 channels of distraction rather than understand that in a hood and orange jumpsuit with no voice or representation, no one could rationally figure out whether they were illegally detained in jail on no charges, either. Guantanamo is sadly, not on the Reality T.V. circuit, and so it remains a stain on our national conscience, that checked out sometime in the 1960s....let's never forget that 75% of the nation was "against" Martin Luther King's politics at the time of his death, as he was attempting to organize sanitation workers on a war on poverty...

These issues are all tragically linked, but rather than make moral connections, we would rather soothe ourselves with the false assurance that if we can carry a gun and "protect ourselves" from those who would steal our precious property or hurt our loved ones, we don't have to examine how all the other policies of our politicians legalize killing and illegal detention all around the world, destroying the ideals we purport make us so great....

The fact that there will be no serious gun control is befitting a nation that can make no serious moral ground on all the hypocrisies it never chooses to examine...

There is no reason why firepower of this magnitude should be so readily available. The only problem with gun advocates, who argue that more armed civilians make for a safer environment, or that bad guys will get outlawed equipment anyways, is that the data never supports them.

In theory discussing at the dinner table, this sounds nice, a wanna be hero jumps in with their gun and saves the day. I am still waiting for that event - that is - am armed citizen to utilize their gun to reduce the level of tragedy to take place among recent tragedies.

Look at Australia, Canada, England, Switzerland, or the US when we made machine gun weapons unavailable to gangsters of the 30's.

Less guns, or reduced the availability of guns and/or limited access to heavier firepower, and voila, such shock: Gun related fatalities are sharply reduced or sharply lower.

Had an earlier congress not outlawed machine guns, can you imagine what Tucson's tragedy would have been like this past week?

The present congress is weak, with much discussion focused on protecting themselves, and virtually no focus on protecting their constituents.

While a strong proponent of gun control legislation (ideally they would be all outlawed if I had my way), I recognize that there is little or no hope of this happening.  As an alternative, why not impose a substantial tax on the manufacture and sale of handguns (or all guns) that would cover the cost associated with freely available; metal detectors at schools and other venues, increased security for government officials and their staff, medical expenses arising from gun violence, or victims compensation funds, just to mention a few.

The sad truth is poor people and cops seem to be most likely to die from gun violence. Until those two groups get tired of it and do something nothing will change.

I'd say a tax on primers (the part of the bullet that starts the firing process and is hard to make yourself) that covers the cost of medical care and response makes sense. That said we do very little that makes sense anymore in America.

Including praying, the elected class proclaims we should do more praying-that stone age practice just this side of sacrificing a chicken. And just as effective.

If I was 20 I'd move to Europe.

I like the idea of Christina's Law.

What's more, we need a law that says that the NRA and gun manufacturers must pay for the lifetime healthcare of all people maimed and injured by guns. So many young men and innocents of real drive by shootings in cities across this country end up injured in the spine or head, and need a lifetime of care. And most of these people have no insurance -- even if they had it, if they can't work after being shot, they lose their job, their income and their ability to pay their premiums, thus losing their healthcare. Hospitals, then states and we taxpayers pay enormous sums to stablize, save them, and follow up with care.
That's one reason our healthcare is one of the highest costing in the world -- because we end up paying for victims of our violent society.
But if Republicans really wanted to save taxpayers money, they would ban all semi-automatic and automatic weapons. The cost of public financed healthcare would plummet!
Yes, let's call for Christine's Law, and stop the insanity.

I have personally seen both the value of citizens having guns (not joking) and the horrible downside.

When I was in grade school in rural Oklahoma, a man shot his son, a student at my school, because he thought a robber had gotten into his house late at night. This is the kind of horror you never forget. In a very small, isolated town, the impact of violence is ten times greater than in a city, because you know the people involved and have a sense of community and caring. The son survived, but everyone in that community learned a lesson.

On the other side of the question, I was fortunate to be a reporter in Portugal during the post revolutionary period. The citizens there emptied out the storehouses of the military getting guns for themselves. The Spanish were rumored to be smuggling in vast supplies of weapons to aid the forces of suppression and oppression. In that case, the guns in the hands of so many citizens, with so many willing to die to stop the imposition of a new dictatorship, acted as a deterrent to the government and its armies when considering the imposition of force against the population.

Guns in a urban environment, in the hands of untrained and inexperienced people, represent great danger and little deterrence. The introduction of one gun into a place of conflict requires more guns and adds to the risk of deadly violence. If a citizen had been immediately present last Saturday in Tucson, there is very little chance they could have stopped the shooting any faster than it was stopped. Additionally, there would have been great risk of the citizen hitting by-standers and even killing more. If the police are called to a scene and someone is shooting to stop a shooting, they would have no idea who the bad guy or the good guy was. They would act with lethal force against the citizen.

Having said all of this, there is a false notion in our cities that the police can and will protect you. Their role, in 9 times out of 10 cases or even more, is to clean up the crime scene, do a thorough investigation and hope that the guilty parties fall into the police net one way or another. While many police officers have given their lives saving citizens, that is not their intention, and police commanders work assiduously to see that their officers are not put in life threatening situations. Unlike the movies, police typically do not enter into highly dangerous situations intentionally. They are sometimes trapped in them.

Take, as one imperfect example, the sad, sad case of the family in Connecticut where three members of the family were killed and only the father survived. From what I know, the police did not enter the house even though they had both the call from the neighbor about the heavily injured father and kidnapped mother. It seems (without a full time line) that the police held back. I wish someone would clarify those events.

Until the creation of the "active shooter profile" following Columbine, police officers were often prevented by their commanders from trying to insert themselves into mass killings. They were often forced to stand back and wait for more information about shootings or until it was certain the shooter had killed himself. In this interval, many people have died.

If there is a burglary in your house and the police are called, they will not rush in with guns drawn to confront the thieves. What they will do depends on the situation and the procedures under which they operate in their department. Most likely, they will stand outside and put officers at the front and back of the house to watch who emerges. (None of this, by the way, should be interpreted to detract in anyway from the bravery of those who do face deadly dangers in carrying out their jobs.) In many parts of the western states, dialing 911 would not bring any assistance in time to do any good. In cities, there is no help if someone comes in and attacks you.

It is quite true, despite all of this, that guns in the house are more of a danger to the occupants than to criminals. They provide an quick path to suicide, accident or one family member shooting another.

I believe the attachment to guns by many rests on a false sense of power. All around us, corporations, the state, employers and others impose on and take away power from the individual. A gun represents a means of self assertion and independence, whether misdirected or not. By the way, there might be no good need for a 31 shot clip, but a one or two shot clip would render a gun totally useless in any situation.

This is a losing issue for Democrats. If you want to seat another 30 to 40 House seats go Republican, then push gun control. We need to build a consensus first and vote later. No one wanted seat belts and later air bags when they came around, but now we know both have saved many lives. We can slow and stop gun violence by a concerted, organized national effort. So far, we have barely started on such a campaign.

Doug Terry at The TerryReport

This is all pretty interesting.  It seems we are ok with mass murder even though gun regulation could reduce the number of people killed, in order to preserve our 'right to bear arms'.  We are also ok with millions of people killed on highways, even though speed limits save lives, but still enjoy driving at excessive speeds to save minutes in daily lives.  Our personal freedom is a key aspect to our individual self worth and we seem always willing to sacrifice the lives of innocents to protect it.  Why doesn't this expression of personal freedom, which allows the deaths of 9 year old girls in the case of gun control, extend to the virtual strip searches that are taking place in airports everyday of all the flying public?  If we are willing to trade vulnerability for personal freedom, why does this not extend to airport security.
